p: Children are more likely than adults to be infected with influenza virus during epidemics [ 1]. Annually, pediatric infections are associated with a high number of emergency room visits and hospitalizations [ 2–5]. This susceptibility of children to influenza virus infection largely results from the absence of preexisting acquired immunity [ 6, 7]. Thus, children can serve as a major reservoir for further prolongation of outbreaks in the community [ 8–10]. Although several studies report prolonged influenza virus replication in children compared with adults, this finding is not consistently reported and remains to be elucidated [ 1, 8–14].
